feed.title: Data Is Plural
feed.subtitle: A weekly newsletter of useful/curious datasets.

entry.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2023.11.15 edition
entry.content:
Trans rights, home schooling, migrant arrivals in Italy, toxic wastewater spills, and coffee tasting.

Â 

ğŸ™ Season 2 of the Data Is Plural podcast is arriving soon. To subscribe via your favorite podcast-listening app, click here.

Â 

ğŸ“¬ Reader Alexandra F published an analysis of US honey consumption and production over time, using data from USDA reports featured in DIP 2022.01.05. (Have you published something with data you found via DIP? Click here to let me know.)

Â 

Trans rights. Myles Williamsonâ€™s Trans Rights Indicator Project â€œprovides insight into the legal situations transgender people faced in 173 countries from 2000 to 2021.â€ The projectâ€™s dataset is â€œthe only public dataset covering trans rights with wide spatial and temporal coverage (to my knowledge),â€ Williamson writes. For each country-year combination, it â€œincludes 14 indicators that capture the presence or absence of laws related to criminalization, legal gender recognition, and anti-discrimination protections.â€ For instance: Does the country require a psychological diagnosis before someone can change their gender on identity documents?

Â 

Home schooling. The Washington Post has gathered data on home-school enrollment figures in dozens of US states and 6,700+ school districts over the past six academic years. Post reporters, with help from students at American University, â€œtrawled state websites, contacted education officials in all 50 states and the District of Columbia and submitted multiple public records requestsâ€ to build the dataset, released last week. Each entry indicates the state/district, school year, and the number of students registered for home schooling. Read more: The Postâ€™s analysis, which â€œreveals that a dramatic rise in home schooling at the onset of the pandemic has largely sustained itself through the 2022-23 academic year, defying predictions [â€¦].â€ [h/t Meghan Hoyer]

Â 

Migrant arrivals in Italy. The Dati Bene Comune campaignâ€™s latest initiative, Liberiamoli tutti! (Letâ€™s free them all!), aims to improve the availability of Italian government data. Its first project has been to convert the interior ministryâ€™s statistics on migrant arrivals from PDF reports into spreadsheets. The extracted information includes daily counts of sea arrivals, twice-monthly totals by nationality, and the number of people in reception centers by center type and Italian region. A nice shout-out: Liberiamoli tutti! says itâ€™s inspired by Data Is Pluralâ€™s sibling, The Data Liberation Project.

Â 

Toxic wastewater spills. For a recent Inside Climate News investigation, Martha Pskowski and Peter Aldhous wrangled data on 10,000+ wastewater spills reported by oil and gas companies to the Texas government between 2013 and 2022. These â€œspill logsâ€ â€” obtained through public records requests, then cleaned and standardized by the journalists â€” correspond to more than 148 million gallons of â€œproduced water,â€ a byproduct of drilling and fracking. The data indicate each spillâ€™s date, location, facility, operator, type of operation, volume of wastewater released, volume recovered, and much more.

Â 

Coffee tasting. Last month, British YouTuber (and former World Barista Champion) James Hoffman virtually hosted the Great American Coffee Taste Test, during which thousands of people simultaneously blind-tasted the same four coffees. Hoffman has published a video summarizing the results, as well as a spreadsheet of anonymized survey responses from 4,000+ participants. It includes tastersâ€™ demographics, general coffee drinking habits and preferences, assessments of the four coffees, and more. [h/t Dan Brady]

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send freshly roasted feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. // Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. // Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and to browse past editions.
entry.summary: Trans rights, home schooling, migrant arrivals in Italy, toxic wastewater spills, and coffee tasting.

entry.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2023.11.01 edition
entry.content:
Opioid settlements, financial offshoring, minority-serving colleges, childcare inspections, and two Zurich buses.

Â 

ğŸ”„ The Marine Regions project, featured in DIP 2021.09.29, has released version 12 of its maritime boundaries dataset, adding â€œnew and more detailed line typesâ€ and â€œupdated with newly established baselines, treaties, and court rulings.â€

Â 

Opioid settlements. OpioidSettlementTracker.com, run by lawyer Christine Minhee, asks: â€œWill opioid settlements be spent in ways that bolster the public health response to drug use?â€ Minhee has compiled a series of spreadsheets to help answer that question. They track the status and reported values of settlements between 14 companies (opioid manufacturers, distributors, and others) and US states (plus DC and Puerto Rico), statesâ€™ plans for spending those settlements, and their promises to publicly report such spending. Read more: â€œ$50 Billion in Opioid Settlement Cash Is on the Way. Weâ€™re Tracking How Itâ€™s Spent,â€ a KFF Health News article using Minheeâ€™s data, part of a broader project on the topic.

Â 

Financial offshoring. The Atlas of the Offshore World â€” â€œa new effort by the EU Tax Observatory,â€ a research group based at the Paris School of Economics â€” aims â€œto inform the global debate around international tax evasion and avoidance.â€ Its four main datasets provide country-level estimates of international profit shifting, offshore financial wealth, offshore real estate ownership, and 50+ years of effective tax rates. Read more: The teamâ€™s â€œGlobal Tax Evasion Report 2024â€ and â€œThe History Behind the Atlas of the Offshore World.â€ [h/t Matt Collin]

Â 

Minority-serving colleges. The MSI Data Project provides a dashboard and dataset focused on colleges and universities that qualify federally as minority-serving institutions either through their mission (e.g., HBCUs) or through enrollment. The project examines institutionsâ€™ funding status, location, student body, and degree granting for 2017â€“2021. It draws on records from the Department of Educationâ€™s â€œeligibility matricesâ€ for each MSI designation and the agencyâ€™s Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System (IPEDS). As seen in: â€œBeyond the Rankings: The College Welcome Guide,â€ by The Hechinger Reportâ€™s Fazil Khan, incorporating data from both IPEDS and the MSI Data Project. [h/t Sarah Butrymowicz]

Â 

Childcare inspections. â€œAcross 41 states, one in ten licensed daycare facilities is overdue for an inspection,â€ according to an analysis by USAFacts, which gathered inspection-timing data for 148,000 facilities. The analysisâ€™s downloadable datasets indicate the number of facilities overdue (versus on-time or unknown) in each state and county, as well as the distribution of days-since-last-inspection in each state. Most of the inspection data had to be programmatically collected from state portals, according to Amber Thomas, except for California, which publishes bulk data (including inspection dates) about all childcare facilities.

Â 

Two Zurich buses. Fabio Widmer et al.â€™s ZTBus dataset provides detailed data from 1,409 â€œdriving missionsâ€ of two electric public transit buses in Zurich, Switzerland. Each mission typically represents a full dayâ€™s operation. The records, which span early 2019 to late 2022, include â€œtime series that represent the power demand, propulsion system, odometry, global position, ambient temperature, door openings, number of passengers, and the dispatch patterns within the public transportation network of the two vehicles.â€

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Dispatch your feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. // Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. // Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and to browse past editions.
entry.summary: Opioid settlements, financial offshoring, minority-serving colleges, childcare inspections, and two Zurich buses.

entry.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2023.10.25 edition
entry.content:
Court-debt jailings, runway incursions, Goldin records, postal code ecology, and spreadsheets from Information is Beautiful.

Â 

Court-debt jailings. â€œIn the absence of a clear picture of debt imprisonment,â€ Stanfordâ€™s Computational Policy Lab and Big Local News â€œset out in 2018 on a first-of-its-kind data integration effort to answer the most basic question of all: how many people are being jailed for unpaid court debts?â€ To do so, the team submitted â€œhundreds of public records requests with county jailsâ€; last month, their Debtorsâ€™ Prisons Project published standardized, anonymized versions of data received from 100 counties (primarily in Texas and Wisconsin), â€œtotalling more than 4 million individual jail booking records,â€ plus warrant data from Oklahoma and Delaware. The datasets indicate (where available) each arresteeâ€™s race, ethnicity, sex, age, state, ZIP code, booking date, release date, and release type, as well as each chargeâ€™s description, severity, and whether it represents a â€œfailure to pay.â€ Read more: The teamâ€™s tutorial for analyzing the data.

Â 

Runway incursions. The Federal Aviation Administration maintains a database of runway incursions, which it defines as â€œany occurrence at an aerodrome involving the incorrect presence of an aircraft, vehicle, or person on the protected area of a surface designated for the landing and take-off of aircraft.â€ It currently contains 30,000+ entries, spanning October 2001 through July 2023; each lists an incursionâ€™s date, category, location, severity, aircraft types, and weather conditions. You can export those elements as a CSV file, but the exports lack the online databaseâ€™s event narratives. As seen in: â€œAirline Close Calls Happen Far More Often Than Previously Knownâ€ and â€œHow a Series of Air Traffic Control Lapses Nearly Killed 131 People,â€ by the NYTâ€™s Sydney Ember and Emily Steel. [h/t Alan Levenson]

Â 

Goldin records. Claudia Goldin, who was awarded 2023â€™s Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences, maintains a faculty webpage with some of the data sheâ€™s created, digitized, and/or improved. They include records from the 1915 Iowa State Census (â€œthe first census in the United States to include information on education and incomeâ€), rosters of eleven US orchestras from the 1930s to 1990s, compulsory education and child labor state laws during the early 1900s, appendix tables for a 1975 paper estimating the economic costs of the US Civil War, and more.

Â 

Postal code ecology. David Willinger et al. have used two major satellite data sources â€”Â the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission and Advanced Spaceborne Thermal Emission and Reflection Radiometer â€” to create ecolo-zip, â€œa novel geospatial dataset that provides a granular-yet-global, parsimonious-yet-rich ecological characterization of over 1.5 million postal codes across 94 countries and regions.â€ Those characterizations include â€œphysical topography (elevation, mountainousness, distance to sea), vegetation (normalized difference vegetation index), and climate (surface temperature).â€

Â 

Beautiful spreadsheets. The team behind infographics powerhouse Information is Beautiful maintains a catalog of the data used in 130+ of their projects, going back to 2009. The entries links to spreadsheet tables that present original research as well as numbers drawn more directly from academic studies, government reports, Wikipedia, and other sources. Recent topics include plastic waste, large language models, and Marvel movies.

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send informative feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. // Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. // Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and to browse past editions.
entry.summary: Court-debt jailings, runway incursions, Goldin records, postal code ecology, and spreadsheets from Information is Beautiful.

entry.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2023.10.11 edition
entry.content:
US income distributions, education reform, Kia/Hyundai thefts, Michigan air permit violations, and dog genomes.

Â 

ğŸ”„ Data librarian Lisa DeLuca has updated her spreadsheet of government agenciesâ€™ Freedom of Information Act libraries (DIP 2021.11.03), now with 360+ entries.

Â 

US income distributions. The Income Distributions and Dynamics in America project combines confidential Census Bureau records and IRS tax forms to generate detailed, downloadable statistics regarding â€œincome percentiles, shares, growth rates, persistence, and more for many U.S. demographic groups at national and state levels.â€ The statistics, which cover 1998 through 2019, are the result of a research partnership between the Minneapolis Fedâ€™s Opportunity & Inclusive Growth Institute and the Census Bureau. The projectâ€™s interactive tools let you track individual and household income percentiles by year, state, race/ethnicity, sex, US/foreign-born status, and age group. Previously: Global income deciles from Kanishka B. Narayan et al. (DIP 2023.06.28). [h/t Alex Albright]

Â 

Education reform. The World Education Reform Database describes 10,000+ education policy changes reported by 180+ countries to international organizations, among other sources. The project, led by education policy scholars Patricia Bromley and Rie Kijima, focuses on â€œsystemic reforms that envision a supra-school administrative level and aim to impact the wider education system, rather than small projects that target individual schools.â€ The database lists each reformâ€™s country, year, name, and summary. Although some of the reforms in the database were introduced hundreds of years ago, the vast majority occurred in the last 50 years.

Â 

Kia/Hyundai thefts. â€œCities around the U.S. are facing a staggering new normal when it comes to stolen cars,â€ writes Motherboard reporter Aaron Gordon, who has been digging into the boom in thefts of Kia and Hyundai vehicles, millions of which lack â€œengine immobilizers, a basic anti-theft device that is legally mandated in Canada and Europe.â€ Gordon has requested car theft data from more than 100 cities, and received it from 43 so far. Heâ€™s updating a spreadsheet that lists each cityâ€™s number of thefts each month, plus the number/percentage that were Kias or Hyundais. Related: Earlier this year, USAFacts obtained and published similar data from 23 US cities.

Â 

Michigan air permit violations. For local news organization Planet Detroit, freelance journalist Shelby Jouppi has built a daily-updating dashboard of air quality permit violations cited by Michiganâ€™s Department of Environment, Great Lakes and Energy. The dataset lists 1,500+ violation notices since 2018; for each, it provides the notice date and findings, facility name and location, and more. To construct it, Jouppi had to scrape individual notice PDFs from the departmentâ€™s website and then extract the information from those documents. Read more: â€œSouthwest Detroit steel slag processor receives 12th air quality permit violation for fallout since 2018,â€ an article by Jouppi based on the data.

Â 

Dog genomes. The Dog10K project aims â€œto coordinate the global effort on genome sequencing in dogs and build a comprehensive resource for the canine community.â€ In a recent Genome Biology article, the team shared data and findings from 1987 individual animals â€” â€œ1611 dogs (321 breeds), 309 village dogs, 63 wolves, and four coyotes.â€ The records include raw sequence data and variation analysis results. [h/t Kim Nguyen]

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Bark your feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. // Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. // Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and to browse past editions.
entry.summary: US income distributions, education reform, Kia/Hyundai thefts, Michigan air permit violations, and dog genomes.

entry.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2023.09.27 edition
entry.content:
Linked historical censuses, fracking fluids, Europopulism, GitHub metrics, and ancient places.

Â 

Censuses, linked. The Census Tree, developed by Kasey Buckles et al., â€œis the largest-ever database of record links among the historical U.S. censuses, with over 700 million links for people living in the United States between 1850 and 1940.â€ By the teamâ€™s estimates, the dataset â€œincludes over 70% of the possible links that could be made for men, and over 60% of possible links for women.â€ To build it, the researchers began with genealogy records from FamilySearch.org, developed a machine learning algorithm to identify additional links, and incorporated data from other census-linking projects. Each Census Tree row connects an individualâ€™s IPUMS identifier in one decadeâ€™s census to their identifier in another. Per the projectâ€™s instructions, youâ€™ll need to download the Census data itself from IPUMS.

Â 

Fracking fluids. Since launching in 2011, FracFocus has become the largest registry of hydraulic fracturing chemical disclosures in the US. The database, available to explore online and download in bulk, contains 210,000+ such disclosures from fracking operators; it details the location, timing, and water volume of each fracking job, plus the names and amounts of chemicals used. The project is managed by the Ground Water Protection Council, â€œa nonprofit 501(c)6 organization whose members consist of state ground water regulatory agenciesâ€. As seen in: The latest installment of the New York Timesâ€™ Uncharted Water series.

Â 

Europopulism. The PopuList, constructed by Matthijs Rooduijn et al., â€œoffers academics and journalists an overview of populist, far-left and far-right parties in Europe from 1989 until 2022.â€ Version 3.0 of the dataset, released last month, lists each partyâ€™s country, local/English names, presence in parliament, and identifiers in the Party Facts (DIP 2019.01.16) and ParlGov (DIP 2018.09.19) databases. It also indicates whether the projectâ€™s comparativists and country experts classified the party (outright or â€œborderlineâ€) as populist, far-right, far-left, and/or euroskeptic, and for which time periods.

Â 

GitHub metrics. GitHubâ€™s new Innovation Graph datasets present a range of quarterly metrics on the code-sharing site, aggregated by â€œeconomyâ€ â€” a concept similar to â€œcountryâ€ but slightly broader. (Antarctica is an â€œeconomyâ€ in the data, for example.) The datasets count the number of developers based in each economy, their repositories and code pushes, most-used programming languages, and more. As noted in the projectâ€™s datasheet, the locations are based on IP addresses, so VPN usage may distort the results. Previously: More-granular GitHub activity via the GH Archive (DIP 2018.02.21). [h/t Kevin Xu]

Â 

Ancient places. Pleiades, â€œa community-built gazetteer and graph of ancient places,â€ has collected data on 40,000+ settlements, roads, rivers, monuments, and many other types of landmarks. It also describes the relationships between them â€” linking, for instance, the Parthenon to the Acropolis and the Acropolis to Athens. Related: ORBIS: The Stanford Geospatial Network Model of the Roman World. Previously: Roman amphitheaters (DIP 2022.06.08) and the Digital Atlas of Roman and Medieval Civilizations (DIP 2020.06.24). [h/t Avi Levin]

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send time-worn feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. // Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. // Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and to browse past editions.
entry.summary: Linked historical censuses, fracking fluids, Europopulism, GitHub metrics, and ancient places.

entry.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2023.09.20 edition
entry.content:
US facility greenhouse gas emissions, net migration estimates, gubernatorial approval, Department of Interior drones, and one million bugs.

Â 

US facility GHG emissions. The EPAâ€™s Facility Level Information on Greenhouse Gases Tool â€œgives you access to greenhouse gas data reported to EPA by large emitters, facilities that inject CO2 underground, and suppliers of products that result in GHG emissions when used in the United States.â€ The information comes from the agencyâ€™s Greenhouse Gas Reporting Program, which also provides bulk data downloads. Per the EPA: â€œApproximately 8,000 facilities are required to report their emissions annually, and the reported data are made available to the public in October of each year.â€ The data, which go back to 2010, indicate the facility type, emissions reported, measurement methods, types of fuel used, and much more. Previously: Climate TRACEâ€™s estimates of the worldâ€™s largest GHG emitters (DIP 2022.11.16). [h/t Terin V. Mayer]

Â 

Net migration estimates. Using national and subnational data on birth rates, death rates, and population counts, Venla Niva et al. have constructed a dataset of estimated net migration for each part of the world, each year between 2000 and 2019. The estimates are available as gridded data (with ~10km resolution) and at three levels of administrative units: national, provincial, and communal. (For the US, the latter two levels correspond to states and counties, respectively.) The researchers have also published an interactive map of the estimates for each administrative unit.

Â 

Gubernatorial approval. Political scientist Matthew M. Singerâ€™s State Executive Approval Database contains the results of 10,000+ gubernatorial approval polls, spanning all 50 states and going back decades. The database, which builds on earlier efforts by Thad Beyle et al., lists each pollâ€™s date, state, governor, pollster, sample size, sample type, ratings scale, percentage of positive/negative responses, and more. Previously: The Executive Approval Project (DIP 2019.10.16), which Singer co-directs.

Â 

DOI drones. Through a FOIA request to the US Department of the Interior, journalist Ben Welsh has obtained and published the agencyâ€™s drone roster. For each of the 850+ remote-controlled aircraft, the dataset lists the agency bureau and office, drone manufacturer, model, cost, serial number, and more. The FOIA request also unearthed spreadsheets listing specific drone flights and multi-flight deployments. Previously: Drone registration data (DIP 2022.12.21), also obtained by Welsh via FOIA.

Â 

Bug shots. Zahra Gharaee et al.â€™s BIOSCAN-1M Insect Dataset contains one million microscope photographs of bugs, each taxonomically classified by experts and supplemented with raw DNA sequences and genetic â€œbarcodeâ€ identifiers. The dataset, part of the broader BIOSCAN initiative, includes 8,300+ species across 3,400+ genera; the specimens were primarily collected in Costa Rica, Canada, and South Africa, using tent-like traps. Previously: Bug splats (DIP 2020.03.04). [h/t Robin Sloan]

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send microscopic feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. // Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. // Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and to browse past editions.
entry.summary: US facility greenhouse gas emissions, net migration estimates, gubernatorial approval, Department of Interior drones, and one million bugs.

entry.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2023.09.13 edition
entry.content:
Political contributions, historical newspaper articles, Prigozhin audio messages, and license plate designs.

Â 

ğŸ“¬ Reader Michael built a map comparing Canadaâ€™s 2023 fire season to earlier years, using data from the Canadian Wildland Fire Information System featured in DIP 2023.06.14. (Have you published something with data you found via DIP? Click here to let me know.)

Â 

ğŸ”„ The Washington Post has obtained and published five more years of prescription opioid data (initially featured in DIP 2019.08.07). The records now cover 2006â€“2019.

Â 

Political contributions, enhanced. Political scientist Adam Bonicaâ€™s Database on Ideology, Money in Politics, and Elections (DIME) gathers â€œ500 million itemized political contributions made by individuals and organizations to local, state, and federal elections covering from 1979 to 2020.â€ The project, which received a major update last month, â€œis intended to make data on campaign finance and elections (1) more centralized and accessible, (2) easier to work with, and (3) more versatile [â€¦].â€ It assigns each contributor a unique identifier, geocodes their stated addresses, quantifies their ideological orientation, and more. The raw data come from several sources, including the Federal Election Commission and OpenSecrets. Related: MoneyInPolitics.wtf, a collaborative project that aims to be â€œAmericaâ€™s most comprehensive dictionary of campaign finance jargon.â€ [h/t Isadora Borges Monroy]

Â 

Historical newspaper articles. Melissa Dell et al.â€™s American Stories dataset contains the text of ~400 million newspaper articles, extracted from ~20 million public-domain scans in the Library of Congressâ€™s Chronicling America project (DIP 2017.08.16). To construct the dataset, the authors built â€œa novel deep learning pipeline that incorporates layout detection, legibility classification, custom OCR, and the association of article texts spanning multiple bounding boxes.â€ For each article, the dataset provides the newspaper name, edition number, date of publication (largely in the 1800sâ€“1920s), page number, headline, byline, and article text. Previously: The LOCâ€™s Newspaper Navigator dataset (DIP 2020.10.07), which extracts visual content from the Chronicling America scans. [h/t Derek M. Jones]

Â 

Prigozhin audio messages. Giorgio Comai has collected and auto-transcribed hundreds of audio messages from Russian mercenary leader Yevgeny Prigozhin, which were posted â€œon his official Telegram channel - the press service of his holding companyâ€ from late 2022 through June 2023. For each transcribed segment within each message, the resulting datasets (one in Russian and one auto-translated into English) include the message ID, time posted, segment timestamp, and segment text. [h/t Federico Caruso]

Â 

The â€œUnknome.â€ The human genome has been sequenced, but what do all those genes do? JoÃ£o J. Rocha et al.â€™s Unknome database assigns a â€œknownnessâ€ score to â€œall protein clusters that contain at least 1 protein from humans or any of 11 model organisms.â€ The score is based on the density of annotations in the Gene Ontology knowledgebase, which bills itself as â€œthe worldâ€™s largest source of information on the functions of genes.â€ The clustering comes from another downloadable database, PANTHER, which contains â€œcomprehensive information about the evolution of protein-coding gene families.â€

Â 

License plate designs. Beautiful Public Dataâ€™s Jon Keegan scraped the websites of every US stateâ€™s (and DCâ€™s) motor vehicle agency to assemble a dataset of 8,291 license plate designs. The dataset provides each designâ€™s name, state, and image. Read more: Keeganâ€™s exploration of the data, which includes a searchable table. Previously: Vanity plates requested in California (DIP 2020.01.29) and New York (DIP 2015.10.21).

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send vain feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. // Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. // Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and to browse past editions.
entry.summary: Political contributions, historical newspaper articles, Prigozhin audio messages, and license plate designs.

entry.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2023.09.06 edition
entry.content:
Eponymic streets, doctors in practice, intra-state ceasefires, metabolisms, and The Onionâ€™s â€œAmerican Voices.â€

Â 

ğŸ“¬ Reader Izzy used the Overture Maps data featured in DIP 2023.08.09 to identify the points in the US furthest from various major brandsâ€™ stores. (Have you published something with data you found via DIP? Click here to let me know.)

Â 

Eponymic streets. Mapping Diversity, created by the European Data Journalism Network, â€œis a platform for discovering key facts about diversity and representation in street names across Europe, and to spark a debate about who is missing from our urban spaces.â€ The interactive analysis of 145,000+ streets in 30 major European cities launched in March, accompanied by spreadsheets calculating city-level statistics and listing all the streets named after women. Last month the team released its full dataset, which provides information for every street examined, plus data for six more cities. Each row indicates a streetâ€™s country, city, and name; whether itâ€™s named after anyone; and, if so, the personâ€™s name, gender, and various attributes from Wikidata, such as occupation and date of birth. Previously: Las Calles de las Mujeres (DIP 2019.05.29).

Â 

Doctors in practice. The Physician and Physician Practice Research Database, published by the US governmentâ€™s Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality, harmonizes data on medical practices from 13 participating states. The public-use files provide each practiceâ€™s ZIP code, number of physicians, most common specialty, organizational NPI, and other characteristics. They also provide statistical aggregates at the 3-digit ZIP code level, such as the number of physicians accepting Medicare and/or Medicaid, average claims per month, and more. [h/t Gary Price]

Â 

Intra-state ceasefires. Govinda Clayton et al.â€™s Civil Conflict Ceasefire Dataset â€œcovers all ceasefires in civil conflict between 1989 and 2020, including multilateral, bilateral and unilateral arrangements, ranging from verbal arrangements to detailed written agreements.â€ The datasetâ€™s 2,200+ ceasefires span 109 conflicts in 66 countries, largely based on news articles discussing the agreements. A team of reviewers manually coded each instance, indicating its type and stated purpose; sides participating; dates declared, entered effect, and ended; and more. Previously: The PA-X Peace Agreements Database (DIP 2018.02.28).

Â 

Metabolisms. Drawing on 20+ published sources, Tori M. Hoehler et al. have compiled a dataset of 10,000+ measurements of metabolic rates of mammals, fish, birds, insects, tree saplings, bacteria, and other living organisms. The dataset includes several types of metabolic rates (primarily basal, field, and maximum), and a mix of individual-organism and species-average measurements.

Â 

Vox populi, except not. The Onion runs a regular feature called â€œAmerican Voices,â€ which presents fake quotes from fake people responding to not-fake events in the news. Cody Winchester has built a spreadsheet listing the headlines, descriptions, and dates for 7,000+ of these features since August 1996; the 23,000+ quotes in them; and the names, occupations, and (almost always recycled) photos of the fictional personae purportedly quoted.

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send made-up feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. // Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. // Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and to browse past editions.
entry.summary: Eponymic streets, doctors in practice, intra-state ceasefires, metabolisms, and The Onionâ€™s â€œAmerican Voices.â€

entry.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2023.08.23 edition
entry.content:
International cancer statistics, SSVF satisfaction surveys, Katherine Dunhamâ€™s data, Singaporeâ€™s wages, and Scotlandâ€™s common good assets.

Â 

ğŸ“¬ Reader Katie used the National Database of Childcare Prices, featured in DIP 2023.04.26, to create an interactive tool for MarketWatch; it compares the average costs in a given county to national averages, the local median income, and (optionally) your own income. (Have you published something with data you found via DIP? Click here to let me know.)

Â 

International cancer statistics. The World Health Organizationâ€™s Global Cancer Observatory provides interfaces to a range of studies and statistics. Its Cancer Today portal features tables, charts, and maps of â€œincidence, mortality and prevalence for year 2020 in 185 countries or territories for 36 cancer types by sex and age group.â€ Those figures come from the latest GLOBOCAN estimates, calculated by the WHOâ€™s International Agency for Research on Cancer based on data from national and regional registries. Note: â€œCaution must be exercised when interpreting these estimates, given the limited quality and coverage of cancer data worldwide at present, particularly in low- and middle-income countries,â€ the researchers warn. Previously: Statistics from the American Cancer Society (DIP 2016.01.27).

Â 

SSVF satisfaction surveys. The Veterans Administrationâ€™s Supportive Services for Veteran Families program aims to â€œto promote housing stability among very low-income Veteran families who reside in or are transitioning to permanent housing.â€ The VA outsources those services to a network of 200+ selected nonprofits, which it grants hundreds of millions of dollars per year. When a veteran exits a granteeâ€™s program, theyâ€™re invited to complete a satisfaction survey. The Data Liberation Project (which, disclosure, I run) filed a FOIA request for the survey data, and received three spreadsheets in return (among other documents), detailing nearly 40,000 anonymized responses from fiscal years 2016â€“20 and 2022.

Â 

Katherine Dunham. Dunhamâ€™s Data, a project led by Kate Elswit and Harmony Bench, â€œexplores the kinds of questions and problems that make the analysis and visualization of data meaningful for dance history, through the case study of 20th century African American choreographer Katherine Dunhamâ€ (1909â€“2006). Drawing on materials â€œheld by seven archives across the United States,â€ the team has built three core datasets, accompanied by essays, visualizations, and code repositories. They â€œdocument the daily itinerary of Dunhamâ€™s touring and travel from the 1930s-60s; the over 300 dancers, drummers, and singers who appeared with her; and the shifting configurations of the nearly 300 repertory entities they performed.â€ [h/t Selena Chau]

Â 

Singaporean wages. Singaporeâ€™s Ministry of Manpower released its 2022 wage tables last month. The tables list the 25th, 50th, and 75th percentiles of basic and gross wages for more than 300 occupations by industry, plus median wages by worker sex, by worker age, and by establishment size. As seen in: The Straits Timesâ€™ benchmarking tool and DIP reader Joses Hoâ€™s interactive chart of Singaporeâ€™s gender wage gaps.

Â 

Scotlandâ€™s Common Good. Scotlandâ€™s Common Good Act, passed in 1491, creates a legal distinction for historical property owned by local authorities â€” often land and buildings, but also â€œmoveable assetsâ€ such as paintings, chains of office, and furniture. CommonGood.scot, launched in April by investigative journalism cooperative The Ferret, presents a searchable, browsable, and downloadable dataset of 2,900+ of these common good assets, compiled largely through freedom of information requests. [h/t Chris H]

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send communally-owned feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. // Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. // Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and to browse past editions.
entry.summary: International cancer statistics, SSVF satisfaction surveys, Katherine Dunhamâ€™s data, Singaporeâ€™s wages, and Scotlandâ€™s common good assets.

entry.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2023.08.09 edition
entry.content:
Mapping material, sweeteners, Federal Reserve communications, English families, and winning numbers.

Â 

ğŸ“¬ Reader Rob C used Josh Fjelstulâ€™s English Football Database, featured in DIP 2023.02.01, to examine what happens after teams get promoted and relegated. (Have you published something with data you found via DIP? Click here to let me know.)

Â 

Much mapping material. The Overture Maps Foundation has released its first datasets, which include 59 million â€œpoints of interestâ€ (landmarks, businesses, parks, etc.), 785 million building outlines, road network data, and administrative boundaries. The initiative, which is steered by several giant tech companies, â€œcould help third-party developers use maps that donâ€™t rely on Google and Apple,â€ The Vergeâ€™s Emma Roth writes. The datasets draw on a range of sources, including the projectâ€™s member-companies, OpenStreetMap, and USGSâ€™s 3D Elevation Program. Read more: â€œExploring the Overture Maps places data using DuckDB, sqlite-utils and Datasette,â€ by Simon Willison, who considers the data release â€œa really big deal.â€ [h/t Avi Levin]

Â 

Sweeteners. The US Department of Agricultureâ€™s Sugar and Sweeteners Yearbook Tables provide â€œsummary statistics on sugar, sugarbeets, sugarcane, corn sweeteners (dextrose, glucose, and high-fructose corn syrup), and honey.â€ Compiled by the agencyâ€™s Economic Research Service from a range of national, international, and industry sources, the statistics are provided as regularly-updated spreadsheets, many of which go back multiple decades. They estimate global and country-level production, supply, distribution, and prices, as well as US imports and consumption. [h/t Sam Larson]

Â 

Federal Reserve communications. Agam Shah et al. have compiled a corpus of key communications by the US Federal Reserveâ€™s Federal Open Market Committee, which â€œcontrols the three tools of monetary policy â€” open market operations, the discount rate, and reserve requirements.â€ Gathered from the Fedâ€™s website, the corpus includes all meeting minutes and speeches from 1996 to mid-October 2022, and all press conferences from April 2011 to mid-October 2022. The published records include the raw text and metadata of each communication, as well as datasets filtered to key sentences. Previously: Federal Reserve Bank directors (DIP 2021.05.05) and Fed forecasts (DIP 2018.02.07).

Â 

English families. The Families of England project, led by economic historians Gregory Clark and Neil Cummins, aims â€œto reconstruct the economic and social position, and the demography, of a representative set of English familiesâ€ over time. A recent paper by Clark includes a public version of the dataset, which â€œdetails the family connections of 422,374 people with rarer surnames in England for births from 1600 to 2022.â€ The dataset, based in part on genealogies from the Guild of One-Name Studies, indicates (where available) each personâ€™s years of birth, marriage, and death, plus indicators of literacy, sex, occupational status, and more. [h/t Derek M. Jones]

Â 

Winning numbers. New York Stateâ€™s Gaming Commission publishes various lottery-related datasets, including the winning numbers for many national and state lotteries, such as Powerball (since 2010), Mega Millions (since 2002), and Pick 10 (since 1987). New York isnâ€™t alone; the Colorado Lottery, for instance, also publishes downloadable drawing histories. Their Powerball results go back to August 2001 and include the jackpot values, unavailable from New York. As seen in: â€œThe jackpot is a lie,â€ by Zach Seward.

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send lucky feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. // Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. // Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and to browse past editions.
entry.summary: Mapping material, sweeteners, Federal Reserve communications, English families, and winning numbers.
